abstract.p: Shoreham Civic Organization president Mary Daum and Wading River Civic Assn president Sid Bail letter agrees with October 10 article on alternative energy sources

block.p: We are pleased to concur with ''Powering Up,'' your editorial endorsing the Long Island Power Authority's plan to locate two wind turbines at the site of the former Shoreham Nuclear Power Station. We are pleased to concur with ''Powering Up,'' your editorial endorsing the Long Island Power Authority's plan to locate two wind turbines at the site of the former Shoreham Nuclear Power Station. For several years we have called on the authority to develop clean, renewable energy sources to supplement Long Island's power supply. At the same time, we also note that the New York State Public Service Commission has formally recognized that garbage incineration is not a renewable energy resource.

As much as Long Island needs additional renewable energy sources, waste incineration is not a reasonable option for achieving Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to use clean, renewable energy for 24 percent of the state's electricity needs by 2013. While the two small wind turbines at Shoreham will have minimal impact on the island's growing need for electricity, they are a step in the right direction.
The writers are the presidents of, respectively, Shoreham Civic Organization and Wading River Civic Association.
